title: Pub review of The Hunworth Bell, Norfolk: 'Retains the soul of an old huntsman’s drinking pub'
text:
Black Shuck is a ghostly dog that, as folklore would have it, roams the coastline and country lanes of East Anglia. The myth goes back to the 14th century, but scanning the bar at The Hunworth Bell in Melton Constable, I see the legend of the hell-hound remains alive and well, in spirit form: you can even order a “Shuck’s Fizz” with Black Shuck gin, which is distilled with Norfolk-grown lavender and sea buckthorn.

The 300-year-old “Hunny Bell”, as it’s locally known, has a traditional beamed bar, a cosy snug and a higher-ceilinged, barn-like dining room at the back. Taken over in 2017 by Ben and Sarah Handley, who also run The Duck Inn in Stanhoe (one of the Estrella Damm Top 50 Gastropubs 2019...
description: Black Shuck is a ghostly dog that, as folklore would have it, roams the coastline and country lanes of East Anglia.
